thread.title: Curt Schilling says he didn’t even watch the Democratic debate - Politics
thread.title_full: Curt Schilling says he didn’t even watch the Democratic debate - Politics

author: boston.com
title: Curt Schilling says he didn’t even watch the Democratic debate - Politics
text:
Curt Schilling wasn’t even watching the Democratic presidential candidates last night when he tweeted at Donald Trump that “ISIS” was winning the debate, he said in an interview on the Dennis & Callahan Show on Wednesday morning.
@realDonaldTrump ISIS
— Curt Schilling (@gehrig38) October 14, 2015 “First of all, I didn’t see one minute of the debate,” Schilling said when asked about the tweet. “I was watching the [MLB] game. I thought, ‘I know who’s up there. I know what they’re saying. I know who’s going to win.’”
 The ISIS tweet came on the heels of another recent controversial tweet about Muslim extremism, in which the former Red Sox pitcher compared the percentage of Muslims who are extremists to the percentage of Germans who were Nazis in 1940. ESPN suspended Schilling for the rest of the baseball season for that “unacceptable” tweet.
Schilling told the radio hosts he couldn’t believe people took Tuesday night’s “ISIS” tweet seriously.
“Somehow, I have no idea how – people were saying, ‘Oh my God, I can’t believe you support ISIS.’ Swear to God. I was like, wait, what?” he said. “I thought it was a joke, but then they started getting liberal and vile so I figured it wasn’t.”
The hosts then began to talk about the big loser of last night’s debate, Lincoln Chafee .
“I know this will come as a big surprise, Curt, but Lincoln Chafee: He’s a moron,” host Gerry Callahan said.
“And in other news, the sun did come up this morning,” Schilling responded.
Photos: The Green Monster through the years.
 Before there was a Green Monster, there was a high wooden fence in the left field of Fenway Park. But it wasn’t as tall, and it wasn’t even green. But the tall structure has been an iconic part of Red Sox history since Fenway opened in 1912. Photo courtesy of Boston Public Library The wall originally had a 10-foot grass incline in front of the fence nicknamed “Duffy’s Cliff,” coined after Red Sox outfielder Duffy Lewis for mastering the uphill territory. The incline was used to balance the grade between street and field level, and to seat overspilled crowds. Boston Globe Archives A five-hour fire destroyed much of Fenway Park in 1934. When the park was rebuilt, a 37-foot left-field wall with an electronic scoreboard replaced the 25-foot tall, left-field fence. Photo courtesy of Boston Public Library The new wall was built out of concrete and tin. Boston Globe Archives s draped down “The Wall,” as it was called at the time, until the ballpark ditched wall-ads in 1947. That same year, the wall was painted green, paving the way for the beloved “Green Monster” nickname. Deniis Brearley / Boston Red Sox Taller, green, and ad-free, the Green Monster started taking its current shape. Boston Globe Archives Then the Green Monster was dismantled before reconstruction began, prior to the 1976 season. Photo courtesy of Boston Red Sox 1976 marked the final restoration of the Green Monster. The use of the wall’s electronic scoreboard ended, National League scores were removed, the interior was replaced, a new exterior replaced the old tin panels, and new 6-foot tall padding protected players when they crashed into the wall. Boston Globe Archives The scoreboard began being updated by hand from behind the wall after the construction of a center-field scoreboard in ‘76. Boston Globe Archives The Green Monster hasn’t been completely rehashed since the ‘70s. Boston Globe Archives Three 25-foot high “Monster Refreshment” Coke bottles hung from the left-field light tower over the Green Monster from 1997 to 2008. The Fenway/Coca-Cola project benefited the Jimmy Fund. Barry Chin / The Boston Globe The Green Monster was given 269 barstool seats in 2003. Until then, the Green Monster had a 23-foot net above to protect stores on Lansdowne Street from flying balls, and a worker would climb up a ladder to retrieve any balls. The ladder is now obsolete but still in place. Stan Grossfeld / The Boston Globe Now, fans regularly enjoy a game from “Monster seats” and look out for flying balls. Jack Maley / Boston Red Sox Ads were also placed on the wall in 2003—that was the first time since ads were banned in 1946. National League scores were re-added to the wall’s hand-operated scoreboard, and permanent ads were added above the wall. Stan Grossfeld / The Boston Globe "A rainbow forms over Fenway Park in Boston, Massachusetts during a team workout before game one of the 2013 World Series between the Boston Red Sox and the St. Louis Cardinals October 22, 2013." Photo courtesy of Billie Weiss / Boston Red Sox
